description: Comprehensive analysis of Bluebook Rules 5-9 covering quotations, abbreviations, numerals, symbols, italicization, capitalization, and titles with detection patterns and error identification strategies

subrules.rule_text: Quotations of fifty or more words should be formatted as block quotations (indented and without quotation marks). Shorter quotations remain in-line with quotation marks. When using a block quotation, maintain the original formatting, including internal quotation marks. Use an ellipsis to indicate omitted material and brackets to indicate changes or additions.

common_errors.description: Quote of 50+ words must be formatted as block quote (indented, no quotation marks)
common_errors.incorrect_example: "This is a very long quotation that contains more than fifty words and should therefore be formatted as a block quotation according to Bluebook Rule 5.1, but it has been incorrectly formatted as an inline quotation with quotation marks, which violates the rule and should be corrected by removing the quotation marks and indenting the text."
common_errors.correct_example: This is a very long quotation that contains more than fifty words and should therefore be formatted as a block quotation according to Bluebook Rule 5.1, and it has been correctly formatted as a block quotation by removing the quotation marks and indenting the text.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Convert to block quote format: remove quotation marks, indent entire passage

common_errors.description: Quote under 50 words should not be block quoted
common_errors.incorrect_example: This short quote should be inline.
common_errors.correct_example: "This short quote should be inline."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Convert to inline quote: add quotation marks, remove indentation

common_errors.description: Block quotation incorrectly includes outer quotation marks
common_errors.incorrect_example: "This is a block quote that incorrectly has quotation marks around it."
common_errors.correct_example: This is a block quote that correctly has no quotation marks around it.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Remove outer quotation marks from block quote

common_errors.description: Block quotation fails to preserve internal quotation marks from original
common_errors.incorrect_example: The court stated that the defendant was negligent.
common_errors.correct_example: The court stated that "the defendant was negligent."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Preserve original internal quotation marks in block quote

detection_patterns.description: Count words in inline quotations to detect 50+ word violations
detection_patterns.post_process: Count words in capture group; flag if >= 50 words

detection_patterns.description: Detect block quotes by indentation pattern

gpt_prompts.prompt: Count the exact number of words in this quotation. If it contains 50 or more words, it must be formatted as a block quotation (indented, without outer quotation marks). If it contains fewer than 50 words, it should be an inline quotation with quotation marks. Return: {"word_count": <number>, "is_compliant": <boolean>, "required_format": "block"|"inline"}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify quotation length and format compliance

gpt_prompts.prompt: Examine this block quotation. Does it properly preserve internal quotation marks that were present in the original source material? Look for quoted speech, quoted terms, or other internal quotes that should be maintained. Return: {"has_internal_quotes": <boolean>, "properly_preserved": <boolean>, "issues": []}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify internal quotation marks are preserved in block quotes

subrules.rule_text: Indicate any alteration to a quoted text with brackets, including added or changed letters or words. Use "[sic]" after an error in the original that is being preserved. When quoting text that itself contains a quotation, alternate between double and single quotation marks (with the outermost quotes determined by the context of your quote).

common_errors.description: Alteration to quoted text not indicated with brackets
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The defendant he was negligent."
common_errors.correct_example: "The defendant [was] negligent."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Enclose all alterations in brackets

common_errors.description: Error in original quotation not marked with [sic]
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The defendent was negligent."
common_errors.correct_example: "The defendent [sic] was negligent."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Add [sic] after preserved errors from original

common_errors.description: [sic] formatted incorrectly (should be in brackets, lowercase, not italicized in brackets)
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The defendent sic was negligent." or "[SIC]" or "[Sic]"
common_errors.correct_example: "The defendent [sic] was negligent."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Format as [sic] - lowercase, in brackets

common_errors.description: Changed capitalization not indicated with brackets
common_errors.incorrect_example: "the Court held..." (when original was "The Court held...")
common_errors.correct_example: "[T]he Court held..."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Bracket altered capital letters

common_errors.description: Nested quotation marks not properly alternated between double and single
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The witness said "I saw it" clearly."
common_errors.correct_example: "The witness said 'I saw it' clearly."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Alternate between double and single quotation marks for nested quotes

common_errors.description: Triple-nested quotations not properly alternated (should go: double > single > double)
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The article stated 'The witness said 'I saw it' clearly' in testimony."
common_errors.correct_example: "The article stated 'The witness said "I saw it" clearly' in testimony."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use double quotes for outermost, single for second level, double for third level

detection_patterns.description: Find all uses of [sic] and variants

detection_patterns.note: Matches quotes containing other quote marks

detection_patterns.description: Detect incorrect double quotes within double quotes

gpt_prompts.prompt: Examine this quotation and compare it to the implied original context. Are there any alterations to the original text (added words, changed words, changed capitalization) that are not properly indicated with brackets? Return: {"has_alterations": <boolean>, "all_properly_bracketed": <boolean>, "issues": [{"location": "", "alteration": "", "should_be": ""}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify all alterations are properly bracketed

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check if this quotation contains any errors from the original source. If errors are preserved, they should be followed by [sic]. If errors were corrected, they should be bracketed. Return: {"has_preserved_errors": <boolean>, "sic_properly_used": <boolean>, "issues": []}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify [sic] is used correctly for preserved errors

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze this quotation for nested quotes. Nested quotations should alternate between double and single quotation marks (outermost determines which). Check if the alternation is correct. Return: {"has_nested_quotes": <boolean>, "nesting_level": <number>, "properly_alternated": <boolean>, "should_be": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify nested quotation marks are properly alternated

subrules.rule_text: Use an ellipsis ("...") to indicate omitted material within a quotation. Do not begin a quote with an ellipsis if the quoted material starts midsentence; simply begin with a lowercase letter (bracketed if needed). Ensure the omission does not alter the fundamental meaning of the quoted text.

common_errors.description: Omitted material within quotation not indicated with ellipsis
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The defendant was negligent and caused harm." (when middle phrase omitted)
common_errors.correct_example: "The defendant was negligent ... and caused harm."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Add ellipsis (...) to indicate omitted material

common_errors.description: Quote incorrectly begins with ellipsis when starting mid-sentence
common_errors.incorrect_example: "... the court held that negligence was proven."
common_errors.correct_example: "[T]he court held that negligence was proven." or "the court held that negligence was proven."
common_errors.fix_instructions: Remove initial ellipsis; use lowercase or bracketed capital letter

common_errors.description: Ellipsis not properly formatted (should be three periods with spaces)
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The court .. held" or "The court .... held"
common_errors.correct_example: "The court ... held"
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use exactly three periods for ellipsis: ...

common_errors.description: Ellipsis spacing incorrect (should have spaces before and after, or formatted as . . .)
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The court...held" or "text...more text"
common_errors.correct_example: "The court ... held" or "text ... more text"
common_errors.fix_instructions: Add spaces before and after ellipsis

common_errors.description: Ellipsis at end of sentence should be four dots (period + ellipsis) if sentence ends
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The defendant was negligent ..."
common_errors.correct_example: "The defendant was negligent ...." (four dots when sentence ends)
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use four dots (. ...) when omission occurs at end of sentence
common_errors.note: Context-dependent; requires knowing if original sentence ended

common_errors.description: Omission fundamentally alters the meaning of the quotation
common_errors.incorrect_example: "The court held ... the defendant liable." (when original said "not liable")
common_errors.correct_example: Use complete relevant portion or paraphrase instead
common_errors.fix_instructions: Do not omit material that changes fundamental meaning

detection_patterns.description: Detect malformed ellipses (wrong number of dots)

gpt_prompts.prompt: Compare this quotation to the original source text. Are there any omissions that are not properly marked with an ellipsis? Return: {"has_omissions": <boolean>, "all_properly_marked": <boolean>, "issues": [{"location": "", "omitted_text": ""}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify all omissions are marked with ellipsis

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check all ellipses in this text for proper formatting. Initial ellipses (at quote start) should be removed if quote starts mid-sentence. Internal ellipses should be three dots with spacing. Terminal ellipses should be four dots if sentence ends. Return: {"ellipses_found": <number>, "all_properly_formatted": <boolean>, "issues": []}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify ellipsis formatting compliance

gpt_prompts.prompt: Compare the quotation with omissions to the original source. Does the omission alter or misrepresent the fundamental meaning of the original text? Return: {"meaning_preserved": <boolean>, "misrepresentation_risk": "none"|"minor"|"major", "explanation": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Ensure omissions don't alter meaning

subrules.rule_text: Use standard abbreviations for case names (table T6), institutional author names (T7), periodical titles (T10), publishing terms (T8), and geographical terms (T10). Do not abbreviate words in textual sentences (except widely known acronyms), but always abbreviate as shown in tables when in citations.

common_errors.description: Word abbreviated in textual sentence when it should be spelled out
common_errors.incorrect_example: The Corp. was negligent in its operations.
common_errors.correct_example: The Corporation was negligent in its operations.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Spell out words in textual sentences; abbreviate only in citations
common_errors.note: Exceptions: widely known acronyms (FBI, CIA, etc.)

common_errors.description: Word not abbreviated in citation when standard abbreviation exists
common_errors.incorrect_example: Smith v. Jones Corporation, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2000).
common_errors.correct_example: Smith v. Jones Corp., 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2000).
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use standard Bluebook abbreviations in citations per Tables T6, T7, T8, T10

common_errors.description: Non-standard abbreviation used instead of Bluebook-approved form
common_errors.incorrect_example: Smith v. Jones Co, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2000). (missing period)
common_errors.correct_example: Smith v. Jones Co., 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2000).
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use exact Bluebook abbreviation forms from tables

common_errors.description: Same term abbreviated inconsistently throughout document
common_errors.incorrect_example: Corporation in one citation, Corp. in another
common_errors.correct_example: Corp. consistently in all citations
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use consistent abbreviation form throughout document

common_errors.description: Geographical term not abbreviated per Table T10
common_errors.incorrect_example: N.Y. Southern District Court (should be S.D.N.Y.)
common_errors.correct_example: S.D.N.Y.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use Table T10 abbreviations for geographical terms

common_errors.description: Widely known acronym unnecessarily spelled out in text
common_errors.incorrect_example: The Federal Bureau of Investigation investigated...
common_errors.correct_example: The FBI investigated...
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use acronym form for widely known terms (FBI, CIA, OSHA, etc.)
common_errors.note: First use may spell out with acronym in parentheses

detection_patterns.description: Detect common abbreviations that may be inappropriate in textual sentences
Detect case names where abbreviations should be used
Detect state names that should be abbreviated in citations

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze this text segment. Determine if it is textual prose or a citation. In textual sentences, most words should be spelled out (except widely known acronyms like FBI, CIA). In citations, standard Bluebook abbreviations must be used. Return: {"is_citation": <boolean>, "abbreviations_found": [{"term": "", "is_appropriate": <boolean>, "should_be": ""}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Distinguish text vs. citation and verify appropriate abbreviation usage

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check if this abbreviation matches the standard Bluebook abbreviation tables (T6 for case names, T7 for institutional authors, T8 for publishing terms, T10 for geographical terms). Return: {"abbreviation": "", "table": "", "is_standard": <boolean>, "correct_form": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify abbreviations match Bluebook tables

gpt_prompts.prompt: Scan the document for uses of this term. Check if it is abbreviated consistently in all citations and spelled out consistently in all textual sentences. Return: {"term": "", "citation_uses": [{"location": "", "form": ""}], "text_uses": [{"location": "", "form": ""}], "is_consistent": <boolean>}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify consistent abbreviation usage throughout document

subrules.rule_text: In text, spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine, and any number that begins a sentence. Use numerals for 100 and above. In citations, use numerals for all numbers (e.g., "115 F.3d 123"). Use symbols (like § and ¶) as appropriate in citations, but in text, use words ("section" or "paragraph") unless referring to a specific section symbol as a symbol.

common_errors.description: Number 0-99 written as numeral in text instead of spelled out
common_errors.incorrect_example: The court considered 45 factors in its decision.
common_errors.correct_example: The court considered forty-five factors in its decision.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Spell out numbers 0-99 in textual sentences

common_errors.description: Sentence begins with a numeral instead of spelled-out number
common_errors.incorrect_example: 150 people attended the hearing.
common_errors.correct_example: One hundred fifty people attended the hearing.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Spell out numbers that begin sentences or restructure sentence

common_errors.description: Number spelled out in citation when numeral should be used
common_errors.incorrect_example: See id. at twenty-three.
common_errors.correct_example: See id. at 23.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use numerals for all numbers in citations

common_errors.description: Number 100 or above spelled out in text when numeral should be used
common_errors.incorrect_example: The statute contains one hundred twenty-three provisions.
common_errors.correct_example: The statute contains 123 provisions.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use numerals for numbers 100 and above in text

common_errors.description: Section symbol (§) used in textual sentence instead of word 'section'
common_errors.incorrect_example: The § requires disclosure of material facts.
common_errors.correct_example: The section requires disclosure of material facts.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use word 'section' in text; use § only in citations

common_errors.description: Paragraph symbol (¶) used in textual sentence instead of word 'paragraph'
common_errors.incorrect_example: The ¶ states the requirements clearly.
common_errors.correct_example: The paragraph states the requirements clearly.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use word 'paragraph' in text; use ¶ only in citations

common_errors.description: Word 'section' used in citation instead of § symbol
common_errors.incorrect_example: See 42 U.S.C. section 1983 (2000).
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use § symbol in citations

common_errors.description: Word 'paragraph' used in citation instead of ¶ symbol
common_errors.incorrect_example: Id. at paragraph 45.
common_errors.correct_example: Id. at ¶ 45.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use ¶ symbol in citations

common_errors.description: Multiple sections not indicated with §§ (double section symbol)
common_errors.incorrect_example: See §§ 101 and 102.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use §§ for multiple sections with range or list format

detection_patterns.note: Numbers 0-99 that may need to be spelled out
Numbers starting sentences must be spelled out

detection_patterns.description: Detect all uses of section symbol
detection_patterns.note: All section symbol uses for context analysis

detection_patterns.description: Detect all uses of paragraph symbol
detection_patterns.note: All paragraph symbol uses for context analysis

detection_patterns.description: Detect spelled-out 'section' or 'paragraph' that may be in citations

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze this text segment containing a number. Determine: (1) Is this in a citation or textual sentence? (2) Is the number 0-99 or 100+? (3) Does it start a sentence? (4) Is it an exception case (date, address, statistical data)? Return: {"number": <value>, "is_citation": <boolean>, "starts_sentence": <boolean>, "is_exception": <boolean>, "should_be_spelled": <boolean>, "correct_form": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Determine if number should be numeral or spelled out

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze the context around this section or paragraph symbol (§ or ¶). Is it in a citation or in textual prose? In citations, symbols should be used. In text, words ('section', 'paragraph') should be used. Return: {"symbol": "", "is_citation": <boolean>, "is_appropriate": <boolean>, "should_be": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify § and ¶ symbols used only in citations

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check if this citation references multiple sections or paragraphs. Multiple sections should use §§ (double symbol) and appropriate formatting (e.g., §§ 101-103 or §§ 101, 103, 105). Return: {"references_multiple": <boolean>, "uses_double_symbol": <boolean>, "format_correct": <boolean>, "should_be": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify proper formatting for multiple section references

rules.rule_title: Italicization for Style and in Unique Circumstances
rules.rule_text: Words may be italicized in text for emphasis or stylistic purposes, but use this sparingly. In legal writing, certain terms are traditionally italicized: words used as words, foreign words not commonly used in English, and letters or numerals referenced as such. Additionally, when a word is being defined, it is often italicized. Beyond these, the Bluebook suggests caution in using italics for style.

common_errors.description: Word used as a word not italicized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The term negligence has a specific legal meaning.
common_errors.correct_example: The term *negligence* has a specific legal meaning.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Italicize words used as words

common_errors.description: Foreign word or phrase not commonly used in English not italicized
common_errors.regex_pattern: \b(per se|de facto|de jure|in rem|in personam|res judicata|stare decisis|mens rea|actus reus|amicus curiae|pro bono|habeas corpus|voir dire|prima facie|ipso facto|sui generis|ab initio|inter alia|res ipsa loquitur|quantum meruit)\b
common_errors.incorrect_example: The doctrine of res judicata prevents relitigation.
common_errors.correct_example: The doctrine of *res judicata* prevents relitigation.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Italicize foreign words and phrases not commonly used in English
common_errors.note: Common legal Latin phrases should be italicized unless fully integrated into English

common_errors.description: Letter or numeral referenced as such not italicized
common_errors.incorrect_example: Add an s to make it plural.
common_errors.correct_example: Add an *s* to make it plural.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Italicize letters or numerals when referenced as such

common_errors.description: Word being defined not italicized
common_errors.incorrect_example: Negligence is defined as the failure to exercise reasonable care.
common_errors.correct_example: *Negligence* is defined as the failure to exercise reasonable care.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Italicize words being defined

common_errors.description: Excessive use of italics for emphasis or style
common_errors.incorrect_example: The defendant was *clearly* *extremely* *reckless* in *every* way.
common_errors.correct_example: The defendant was clearly extremely reckless in every way.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Use italics for emphasis sparingly; remove excessive stylistic italics

common_errors.description: Common foreign word fully integrated into English incorrectly italicized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The *cafe* was located downtown. or *et cetera*
common_errors.correct_example: The cafe was located downtown. or etc.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Do not italicize foreign words fully integrated into English (e.g., cafe, etc.)
common_errors.note: Common words like 'etc.' from 'et cetera' are not italicized

common_errors.description: Case name italicization incorrect (should be italicized in text, may be underlined in court docs)
common_errors.incorrect_example: In Brown v. Board of Education, the Court held...
common_errors.correct_example: In *Brown v. Board of Education*, the Court held...
common_errors.fix_instructions: Italicize case names in textual references
common_errors.note: In court documents, underlining may be used instead

detection_patterns.description: Detect italicized text in various formats
Detect common Latin legal phrases that should be italicized
detection_patterns.regex: \b(per se|de facto|de jure|in rem|in personam|res judicata|stare decisis|mens rea|actus reus|amicus curiae|pro bono|habeas corpus|voir dire|prima facie|ipso facto|sui generis|ab initio|inter alia|res ipsa loquitur|quantum meruit|ex parte|pro rata|nunc pro tunc|inter vivos|ex post facto|bona fide)\b
detection_patterns.note: Should be italicized unless in common usage
Word being defined should be italicized

detection_patterns.description: Detect case names that should be italicized
detection_patterns.note: Case names should be italicized in text

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze this text for words used as words (e.g., 'the word negligence', 'the term liability'). These should be italicized. Return: {"words_as_words": [{"word": "", "is_italicized": <boolean>, "should_be_italicized": <boolean>}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify words used as words are italicized

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check this text for foreign words and phrases. Determine if they are commonly used in English (like 'cafe', 'etc.') or should be italicized (like 'res judicata', 'mens rea'). Return: {"foreign_terms": [{"term": "", "is_common_english": <boolean>, "should_be_italicized": <boolean>, "is_italicized": <boolean>}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify appropriate italicization of foreign terms

gpt_prompts.prompt: Review the use of italics in this passage. Identify if italics are used excessively for emphasis or style. Bluebook recommends sparing use of stylistic italics. Return: {"total_italic_uses": <number>, "stylistic_uses": <number>, "excessive": <boolean>, "recommendations": []}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Identify excessive stylistic italicization

gpt_prompts.prompt: Identify case names in this text. In textual references (not citations), case names should be italicized or underlined. Return: {"case_names": [{"name": "", "is_in_text": <boolean>, "is_italicized": <boolean>, "should_be_italicized": <boolean>}]}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify case name italicization in text

rules.rule_text: Capitalize references to specific constitutional amendments ("First Amendment"), specific acts or laws ("Civil Rights Act"), titles of court documents (when referring to a specific document, e.g., "Plaintiff's Motion"), and titles of periodicals in citations (per Bluebook rules). Do not capitalize generic references ("the amendment" or "the act") or terms like "federal" or "state" unless part of an official name. Additionally, follow specific capitalization rules for judges' titles (rule 9) and court names ("Supreme Court" when referring to SCOTUS, etc.).

common_errors.description: Specific constitutional amendment not capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The first amendment protects free speech.
common_errors.correct_example: The First Amendment protects free speech.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize specific amendment references (First Amendment, Fourteenth Amendment, etc.)

common_errors.description: Generic amendment reference incorrectly capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The Amendment was ratified in 1791.
common_errors.correct_example: The amendment was ratified in 1791.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase generic amendment references ('the amendment', 'an amendment')

common_errors.description: Specific act or statute not capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The civil rights act of 1964 prohibits discrimination.
common_errors.correct_example: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize specific act names (Civil Rights Act, Voting Rights Act, etc.)

common_errors.description: Generic act reference incorrectly capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The Act was passed last year.
common_errors.correct_example: The act was passed last year.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase generic act references when not referring to a specific act
common_errors.note: Context-dependent; 'the Act' may refer to specific act mentioned earlier

common_errors.description: Specific court document title not capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: In plaintiff's motion for summary judgment...
common_errors.correct_example: In Plaintiff's Motion for Summary Judgment...
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize titles of specific court documents

common_errors.description: Generic document reference incorrectly capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The plaintiff filed a Motion yesterday.
common_errors.correct_example: The plaintiff filed a motion yesterday.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase generic document references

common_errors.description: Words 'federal' or 'state' capitalized when not part of official name
common_errors.incorrect_example: The Federal government enacted the regulation.
common_errors.correct_example: The federal government enacted the regulation.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase 'federal' and 'state' unless part of official name
common_errors.note: Capitalize in: 'Federal Circuit', 'State of California', etc.

common_errors.description: Court name capitalization incorrect
common_errors.incorrect_example: The supreme court held... or The Court held... (referring to district court)
common_errors.correct_example: The Supreme Court held... (for SCOTUS) or The court held... (for lower courts)
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize 'Court' for Supreme Court of the United States; lowercase for other courts unless full name

common_errors.description: Periodical title in citation not properly capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: 120 harvard law review 456 (2007).
common_errors.fix_instructions: Follow Bluebook capitalization rules for periodical titles in citations

common_errors.description: Word 'Constitution' capitalization incorrect
common_errors.incorrect_example: The constitution protects individual rights. or ...a state Constitution...
common_errors.correct_example: The Constitution protects individual rights. (U.S.) or ...a state constitution...
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize 'Constitution' when referring to U.S. Constitution; lowercase for state constitutions unless full name

detection_patterns.note: Check if specific amendments are capitalized

detection_patterns.description: Detect references to acts and statutes

detection_patterns.note: Document titles should be capitalized when specific
Should be lowercase unless part of official name

gpt_prompts.prompt: Determine if this amendment reference is specific or generic. Specific references (First Amendment, Fourteenth Amendment) should be capitalized. Generic references ('an amendment', 'the amendment' without prior specific reference) should be lowercase. Return: {"reference": "", "is_specific": <boolean>, "should_be_capitalized": <boolean>, "is_capitalized": <boolean>}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify amendment capitalization

gpt_prompts.prompt: Determine if this act reference is specific or generic. Specific acts (Civil Rights Act, Americans with Disabilities Act) should be capitalized. Generic references ('an act', 'the act' without prior specific reference) should be lowercase. Return: {"reference": "", "is_specific_act": <boolean>, "should_be_capitalized": <boolean>, "is_capitalized": <boolean>}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify act/statute capitalization
gpt_prompts.note: 'The Act' may refer to previously mentioned specific act

gpt_prompts.prompt: Determine if this is a reference to a specific court document or a generic document. Specific document titles (Plaintiff's Motion for Summary Judgment) should be capitalized. Generic references ('a motion', 'the brief') should be lowercase. Return: {"reference": "", "is_specific_document": <boolean>, "should_be_capitalized": <boolean>, "proper_form": ""}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify court document title capitalization

gpt_prompts.prompt: Analyze this court reference. 'Supreme Court' refers to SCOTUS and should be capitalized. 'Court' capitalized alone refers to the court deciding the case being discussed. Other courts should use lowercase 'court' unless the full official name is given. Return: {"court_reference": "", "refers_to": "SCOTUS"|"case_court"|"other", "should_be_capitalized": <boolean>, "is_capitalized": <boolean>}
gpt_prompts.use_case: Verify court name capitalization

gpt_prompts.prompt: Check if 'federal' or 'state' is part of an official name. Capitalize if part of official name (Federal Circuit, State Department, State of California). Lowercase if used generically (federal government, state law). Return: {"term": "", "is_official_name": <boolean>, "should_be_capitalized": <boolean>, "is_capitalized": <boolean>}

rules.rule_title: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court
rules.rule_text: Capitalize the titles of judges and officials when used before a name ("Chief Justice Marshall") or when referring to a specific person ("the President"). Do not capitalize when used generically ("any justice may..."). Terms of court (like "Fall Term") are capitalized when naming a specific term of a specific court. Always capitalize "Court" when naming the U.S. Supreme Court or when the reference is to the court in a case name in text ("the Court held..."). Otherwise, lowercase "court".

common_errors.description: Judge or official title before a name not capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: In chief justice Roberts' opinion...
common_errors.correct_example: In Chief Justice Roberts' opinion...
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize titles when used before names

common_errors.description: Title referring to specific person not capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: The president issued an executive order. (referring to current President)
common_errors.correct_example: The President issued an executive order.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize titles when referring to a specific identified person

common_errors.description: Generic title incorrectly capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: Any Justice may write a dissenting opinion.
common_errors.correct_example: Any justice may write a dissenting opinion.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase titles used generically (not referring to specific person)

common_errors.description: Specific term of court not capitalized or generic term capitalized
common_errors.incorrect_example: During the fall term, the court heard... or The Term begins in October. (generic)
common_errors.correct_example: During the Fall Term 2020, the Court heard... or The term begins in October.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize specific terms of specific courts (October Term 2020); lowercase generic references

common_errors.description: Incorrect 'Court' capitalization per Rule 9
common_errors.incorrect_example: The court held that... (when referring to Supreme Court in discussed case)
common_errors.correct_example: The Court held that... (when discussing SCOTUS case opinion)
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize 'Court' when referring to Supreme Court or the court in a case being discussed; lowercase otherwise

common_errors.description: Title after name incorrectly capitalized when generic
common_errors.incorrect_example: John Roberts, Chief Justice, wrote the opinion.
common_errors.correct_example: John Roberts, chief justice, wrote the opinion. (or: Chief Justice John Roberts wrote...)
common_errors.fix_instructions: Lowercase titles after names unless part of formal title construction
common_errors.note: Before name: capitalize. After name: generally lowercase unless formal construction

common_errors.description: Judicial title incorrectly abbreviated
common_errors.incorrect_example: J. Roberts dissented.
common_errors.correct_example: Justice Roberts dissented.
common_errors.fix_instructions: Spell out judicial titles in text; abbreviate only in case names and citations

common_errors.description: Reference to multiple justices with incorrect capitalization
common_errors.incorrect_example: Justices Roberts and Alito dissented. (when used generically) or justices Roberts and Alito (when specific)
common_errors.correct_example: Justices Roberts and Alito dissented. (specific persons) or Several justices dissented. (generic)
common_errors.fix_instructions: Capitalize 'Justices' when referring to specific named persons; lowercase when generic

implementation_notes.regex_limitations: Many errors require context analysis and cannot be detected by regex alone. Errors marked with 'requires_gpt': true need AI-assisted verification.

severity_levels.critical: Changes meaning or seriously misrepresents source material
severity_levels.major: Clear Bluebook violation that affects professional quality
severity_levels.minor: Style or formatting issue that should be corrected

implementation_notes.auto_fixable_notes: Errors marked auto_fixable: true can be corrected programmatically with high confidence. Others require human judgment or context.
implementation_notes.detection_strategy: Use multi-pass approach: (1) regex-based pattern detection for quick wins, (2) GPT analysis for context-dependent rules, (3) human review for critical errors
integration_recommendations: Implement regex patterns first for quick detection of common errors
